children.value: for vector norms and for the Frobenius norm of a matrix, which is like stacking the matrix into a single vector before taking the 2-norm.
Most of the time we want to use
, which is an induced matrix norm. The default is the 2-norm.
You can get the 1-norm as well.
, the matrix 1-norm is equivalent to the maximum of the sums down the columns (in absolute value).
to sum along a dimension of a matrix. You can also sum over the entire matrix by omitting the
functions also work along one dimension or over an entire matrix. To get both values at once, use

# Sum down the rows (1st matrix dimension):
maximum( sum(abs.(A), dims=1) )
-norm and check our formula for it.

# Sum across columns (2nd matrix dimension):
maximum( sum(abs.(A), dims=2) )
Next we illustrate a geometric interpretation of the 2-norm. First, we will sample a lot of vectors on the unit circle in

children.html: R2\mathbb{R}^2R2

children.value: You can use functions as values, e.g., as elements of a vector.
To create an array of plots, start with a

plot(aspect_ratio=1, layout=(1, 2),
    xlabel=L"x_1",  ylabel=L"x_2")
plot!(x[1, :], x[2, :], subplot=1, title="Unit circle")
